articles.headline: Tesla Has Something Hotter Than Cars to Sell: Its Story
articles.snippet: The electric-car maker is the latest company to become a market darling based not on what it has achieved but on a vision of a dominant future.
articles.abstract: The electric-car maker is the latest company to become a market darling based not on what it has achieved but on a vision of a dominant future.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Tesla shares surged past $300 this week and the company’s market value surpassed Ford’s, even its founder, Elon Musk, acknowledged on Twitter that the company was “absurdly overvalued if based on the past.”

articles.headline: Dozens of U.S. Missiles Hit Air Base in Syria
articles.snippet: The strike was in response to the Syrian government’s chemical weapons attack this week.
articles.abstract: The strike was in response to the Syrian government’s chemical weapons attack this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said Thursday night that the United States had carried out a missile strike in Syria in response to the Syrian government’s chemical weapons attack this week, which killed more than 80 civilians.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon, Helene Cooper and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: C.I.A. Had Evidence of Russian Effort to Help Trump Earlier Than Believed
articles.snippet: Former government officials said the agency told senior lawmakers last summer that it had information indicating that Russia was working to help get President Trump elected.
articles.abstract: Former government officials said the agency told senior lawmakers last summer that it had information indicating that Russia was working to help get President Trump elected.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The C.I.A. told senior lawmakers in classified briefings last summer that it had information indicating that Russia was working to help elect Donald J. Trump president, a finding that did not emerge publicly until after Mr. Trump’s victory months later, former government officials say.

articles.headline: Twitter Sues the Government to Block the Unmasking of an Account Critical of Trump
articles.snippet: Twitter said it had a received a summons to reveal the owner of a so-called alt-account, whose owners say they are dissident current or former government workers.
articles.abstract: Twitter said it had a received a summons to reveal the owner of a so-called alt-account, whose owners say they are dissident current or former government workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter sued the federal government on Thursday to block the unmasking of an anonymous account that has posted messages critical of the Trump administration and has claimed to have ties to a government agency.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Will Allow 23andMe to Sell Genetic Tests for Disease Risk to Consumers
articles.snippet: Lifting an earlier moratorium, the agency said the company could report the risks for 10 diseases under certain controls.
articles.abstract: Lifting an earlier moratorium, the agency said the company could report the risks for 10 diseases under certain controls.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time, the Food and Drug Administration said it would allow a company to sell genetic tests for disease risk directly to consumers, providing people with information about the likelihood that they could develop various conditions, including Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s.

articles.headline: Trump and Warren Agree? Maybe, on Plan to Shrink Big Banks
articles.snippet: President Trump and Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat harshly critical of Wall Street, may both favor separating retail and investment banking.
articles.abstract: President Trump and Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat harshly critical of Wall Street, may both favor separating retail and investment banking.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump has vowed to roll back financial regulation, saying that it is preventing banks from lending and businesses from growing.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: As Anger at O’Reilly Builds, Activists Use Social Media to Prod Advertisers
articles.snippet: Advertisers are in the cross hairs of populist activists, aided by social media, who are demanding that brands quickly take positions on issues.
articles.abstract: Advertisers are in the cross hairs of populist activists, aided by social media, who are demanding that brands quickly take positions on issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: In this age of rage, Madison Avenue is finding itself on red alert.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: In Battle for Trump’s Heart and Mind, It’s Bannon vs. Kushner
articles.snippet: The escalating feud between the chief White House strategist and the president’s son-in-law reflects a larger struggle to guide the direction of the Trump presidency.
articles.abstract: The escalating feud between the chief White House strategist and the president’s son-in-law reflects a larger struggle to guide the direction of the Trump presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thick with tension, the conversation this week between Stephen K. Bannon, the chief White House strategist, and Jared Kushner, the president’s son-in-law and senior adviser, had deteriorated to the point of breakdown.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Jeremy W. Peters and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Panicked Borrowers, and the Education Department’s Unsettling Silence
articles.snippet: Teachers, doctors and others in the public service loan forgiveness program seek guidance on whether they are truly eligible to erase their student loan debt.
articles.abstract: Teachers, doctors and others in the public service loan forgiveness program seek guidance on whether they are truly eligible to erase their student loan debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was bad enough late last month when the Education Department, in a legal filing, informed the nation’s public servants that they shouldn’t trust its administrator’s word about whether their student loans qualify for its debt forgiveness program.

articles.headline: Job Growth Loses Steam as U.S. Adds 98,000 in March
articles.snippet: The showing was the weakest in nearly a year and followed two robust increases. But unemployment fell to 4.5 percent, the lowest in almost a decade.
articles.abstract: The showing was the weakest in nearly a year and followed two robust increases. But unemployment fell to 4.5 percent, the lowest in almost a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Looking for a Trump bump in the economy? Keep waiting.

articles.headline: NRG, a Power Company Leaning Green, Faces Activist Challenge
articles.snippet: Two hedge funds have installed board members, one a climate-science skeptic, with the company’s renewable-energy business possibly in play.
articles.abstract: Two hedge funds have installed board members, one a climate-science skeptic, with the company’s renewable-energy business possibly in play.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the years, NRG, a leading independent power producer whose fleet once depended heavily on coal, has made big bets on low-carbon energy technologies and publicized its embrace of sustainability as essential to its future.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Acting on Instinct, Trump Upends His Own Foreign Policy
articles.snippet: It was hard to reconcile the anguished president with the snarky critic who advised his predecessor not to strike.
articles.abstract: It was hard to reconcile the anguished president with the snarky critic who advised his predecessor not to strike.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — The images were heartbreaking: Children gasping and choking for breath, their mouths foaming. A grief-stricken father, cradling the lifeless bodies of his two children, swaddled in white blankets. But they were also familiar, a harrowing flashback to 2013, when the Syrian government unleashed the last major poison gas attack on its own people.

articles.headline: Syria Strike Puts U.S. Relationship With Russia at Risk
articles.snippet: The attack showed the dangers of Russian and American forces’ operating in proximity. President Vladimir V. Putin called it a “significant blow” to the relationship.
articles.abstract: The attack showed the dangers of Russian and American forces’ operating in proximity. President Vladimir V. Putin called it a “significant blow” to the relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American military strike against Syria threatened Russian-American relations on Friday as the Kremlin denounced President Trump’s use of force and the Russian military announced that it was suspending an agreement to share information about air operations over the country, devised to avoid accidental conflict.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Neil MacFarquhar and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Neil Gorsuch Confirmed by Senate as Supreme Court Justice
articles.snippet: He becomes the 113th justice of the Supreme Court, capping a political brawl that lasted for more than a year and tested constitutional norms inside the Capitol’s fraying upper chamber.
articles.abstract: He becomes the 113th justice of the Supreme Court, capping a political brawl that lasted for more than a year and tested constitutional norms inside the Capitol’s fraying upper chamber.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Neil M. Gorsuch was confirmed by the Senate on Friday to become the 113th justice of the Supreme Court, capping a political brawl that lasted for more than a year and tested constitutional norms inside the Capitol’s fraying upper chamber.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Matt Flegenheimer
